issues.description: The problem statement (Part 2, paragraph describing the controller contract) incorrectly says “Each method takes a Consumer<List<Note>> parameter”, while the template and solution PersonController methods use Consumer<List<Person>>. This is a cross-artifact parameter-type mismatch in the textual specification that can confuse students about the expected callback type when implementing the PersonController.
issues.suggested_fix: Fix the problem statement so it refers to Consumer<List<Person>> (not Consumer<List<Note>>) when describing the PersonController method signatures/callbacks. This aligns the textual description with the template and solution code and avoids confusion.

issues.description: Problem statement refers to the controller methods as taking a Consumer<List<Note>> (lines 150-152) while the template and solution PersonController methods use Consumer<List<Person>>. The problem text therefore names the wrong generic type ('Note' instead of 'Person') for the PersonController callbacks. This typo creates a mapping confusion: students may look for or try to implement Consumer<List<Note>> signatures for person-related methods even though the template and solution clearly expect Consumer<List<Person>>.
issues.suggested_fix: In the problem statement replace the incorrect type Consumer<List<Note>> with Consumer<List<Person>> (or reword to 'Each method takes a Consumer<List<Person>> parameter, which is called with the controller's internal list of persons'). This aligns the textual requirement with the template and solution method signatures and avoids confusion.
